title: MTA's post-Sandy resiliency efforts: A lot done, a lot left to do
text:
Of the nine subway tunnels inundated by Sandy, the MTA has repaired and strengthened seven. | AP Photo MTA's post-Sandy resiliency efforts: A lot done, a lot left to do

Seven years ago, Hurricane Sandy’s storm surges swallowed "the world’s largest subway yard.”

On Tuesday, subway executives gathered at the site of that Coney Island Yard Complex to highlight all they have done across the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to mitigate against the possibility it will suffer such catastrophe again — even as they acknowledged that their efforts remain a work in progress.

Story Continued Below

“We’ve got a great deal of work to do,” said MTA Chairman and CEO Pat Foye.

When it hit in 2012, Hurricane Sandy pummeled New York City's transit system. That it got up and running again so quickly masked the lasting damage wrought by the storm waters. Since then, the MTA has been methodically rehabilitating its assets.

Of the nine subway tunnels inundated by Sandy, the MTA has repaired and strengthened seven. The MTA’s two car tunnels — the Queens Midtown and the Hugh L. Carey — now have 25-ton floodgates. The MTA has devised temporary anti-flooding devices for the 3,500 places where flood waters can enter the subway system. At the Coney Island Yard, where six subway lines converge, the MTA is installing a 12,000-foot-long steel perimeter wall that construction workers have driven 30 feet into the ground. The work there should be completed within three years. Two other vulnerable subway yards are still undergoing repairs, too.

All of which prompted a reporter to ask if the MTA is prepared, right now, for another storm like Sandy.

“The answer is 'much better prepared,'” Foye said.

Foye, outgoing MTA Managing Director Ronnie Hakim and Sandy-era MTA Chairman and CEO Joe Lhota — who was credited with helping quickly resurrect the system — spoke from beneath a blue pop-up tent in the drizzle. Work trains passed slowly behind them.

“We learned valuable lessons from Sandy, and one of the most sobering lessons was that severe weather is no longer an anomaly, and the effects of climate change have only worsened,” Foye said.

The Coney Island Yard sits in low-lying southern Brooklyn, close to Coney Island Creek. Sandy sent 27 million gallons of water and debris rushing into it, damaging 18 subway cars, more than 22 miles of power and communications cable, more than 39,000 feet of track, more than 300 signal locations and nearly 200 switches.

Work to permanently protect the rail yard began last year, as part of the MTA's $7.7 billion hurricane recovery and resiliency plan. The MTA has thus far spent down about half of that $7.7 billion, according to spokesperson Abbey Collins.

“We are using available funds responsibly,” she said.

About a year ago, Columbia University scientist Klaus Jacob took part in an analysis of the MTA’s resiliency plans, with a particular focus on the subways.

After analyzing the MTA’s various methods for temporarily blocking the holes where floods might rush in, Jacob and his team determined the MTA was “in pretty good shape for a couple of decades,” he said in an interview on Tuesday. His team had one major caveat.

“The one thing that we pointed out to the MTA is that it’s a one-line defense, so if there are any failures in the system, in particular in key locations ... then you probably have a situation as if the other several thousand protective devices wouldn’t be there,” he said. “Our question to the MTA was largely one of redundancy.”
description: Subway executives gathered Tuesday to highlight all they've done to mitigate against future disasters — but they acknowledged it's a work in progress.
